item.title: About Dr. Chamara Basnayake
item.description:
About Dr. Chamara Basnayake

Dr. Chamara Basnayake is a leading gastroenterologist and the founder of PoopColor.info. With over 15 years of experience in digestive health, Dr. Basnayake has dedicated his career to demystifying complex medical topics and making gut health accessible to everyone.

Please update this section with your specific credentials, such as your medical school, residency, fellowships, and any board certifications. This is a critical component for establishing E-E-A-T.

item.title: The Ultimate Guide to Stool Color: What Your Poo Is Telling You
item.description: Our complete guide to stool color. From brown to green, black, yellow, red, white, or orange, learn what your poo color means for your digestive health.

item.title: Do you have orange stools?
item.description: Discover common causes, health implications, and when to see a doctor if you have orange stools. Learn more about symptoms here!

item.title: Black or Tarry Stool: When to Worry
item.description: Black or tarry stool can signal serious health issues. Learn causes, symptoms, and when to seek urgent medical attention here.

item.title: Red Stool vs. Blood in Stool: What’s the Difference?
item.description: Discover the key differences between red stool and blood in stool, symptoms, causes, and when to seek medical attention.

item.title: What your stool color says about your health
item.description: Discover what your stool color reveals about your digestive health, potential medical conditions, and when to seek professional care.

item.title: Is brown the only normal color of poo?
item.description: Discover the truth about poop colors: Is brown the only normal shade? Learn what different stool colors indicate about health.

item.title: What does coffee do the color and consistency of my poo?
item.description: Discover how coffee affects your poop’s color and consistency, revealing impacts on digestion, hydration, and gut health in this blog.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.description:
Last updated: May 11, 2025

Your privacy is important to us. This policy explains:

  1. What we collect
    We do not collect any personally identifiable information. All image analysis happens locally in your browser—nothing is uploaded to our servers.

  2. Cookies & Analytics
    We use anonymized Google Analytics to track page views. No personally identifiable data is stored.

  3. Third-party ads
    We serve ads via Google AdSense. Those networks may set cookies via their ad code—please refer to their respective privacy policies for details.

item.title: Why can i see food in my poo?
item.description: Discover why you can see food in your poo, common causes, digestive health tips, and when to consult a doctor.

item.title: Why is my poo white?
item.description: Discover the causes of white stool, potential health concerns, and when to see a doctor for white-colored poop issues.

item.title: What happens to the colour of my poo when I am dehydrated
item.description: Discover how dehydration affects stool color, causes darker shades, and learn hydration tips to maintain healthy bowel movements and digestion

item.title: What happens to the colour of my poo when I take antibiotics
item.description: Discover how antibiotics affect your poop color, reasons for changes, and when to consult a doctor for safe digestive health awareness.

item.title: Bile Salts and Golden Stool
item.description: Learn how bile salts contribute to the golden-brown color of your stool and what it signifies for your digestive health.

item.title: Why Is My Poo Pale - common causes
item.description: Discover common causes of pale poo, symptoms to watch for, and when to see a doctor for potential liver or digestive issues.

item.title: Why Is My Poo Yellow? 7 Common Causes
item.description: Discover 7 common causes of yellow poo, including diet, digestion issues, and infections, to understand your bowel health better.

item.title: Black Stool After Iron Supplements: What to Know
item.description: Discover why black stool occurs after iron supplements, its causes, when to worry, and tips for managing side effects effectively.

item.title: Blood in Stool vs Red Foods: How to Tell
item.description: Learn how to distinguish blood in stool from red-colored foods with expert tips to identify causes and when to seek help.

item.title: Why Is My Stool Green? 7 Common Causes
item.description: Discover 7 common causes of green stool, symptoms to watch for, and when to see a doctor for digestive health concerns.

item.title: Bile Acid Diarrhea
item.description: Learn how bile acid diarrhea can affect your stool color, causing shades of green or yellow, and what this means for your digestive health.

item.title: Dehydration And Hard Stool
item.description: Learn how dehydration affects not only the consistency of your stool, making it hard, but also its color, often making it darker.

item.title: High-Fat Meals And Yellow Stool
item.description: Understand the connection between high-fat meals and yellow stool, and learn how your diet can influence your stool’s color.

item.title: When Stools Turn Mysterious Hues
item.description: A quick guide to why your stool might change to mysterious colors like red, green, black, yellow, or pale, and what each hue signifies.

item.title: Why Is My Stool Changing Color? Foods, Meds, Infections Causes
item.description: Learn about the common causes of stool color changes, including foods, medications, and infections, and what each color might signify about your health.

item.title: Why Is My Stool Dark After Taking Iron Pills or Antibiotics?
item.description: Learn why taking iron supplements or certain antibiotics can cause your stool to turn dark or black, and why it’s usually a harmless side effect.

item.title: Beetroot and Red Stool
item.description: Learn why eating beetroot can cause your stool to turn red or pink, a common and harmless phenomenon known as beeturia.

item.title: Iron Supplements and Black Stool
item.description: Find out why taking iron supplements can turn your stool black or dark green, a common and usually harmless side effect.
